com.github.mdsimmo.bomberman.utils

Interface Region

  • All Superinterfaces:
    org.bukkit.configuration.serialization.ConfigurationSerializable, Serializable
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    Box, CombinedRegion

    public interface Region
extends Serializable, org.bukkit.configuration.serialization.ConfigurationSerializable
    A region defines a collection of a bunch of blocks. Regions can be any shape or size and can span multiple worlds. A region should be immutable.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      boolean contains(Place p)
      Convenience method for contains( p.world, p.x, p.y, p.z ).
      boolean contains(org.bukkit.World w, int x, int y, int z)
      Tests if the x, y and z points of the given world are within this region.
      Region shift(int x, int y, int z)
      Creates a new region that is the same as this region but shifted by the specified amount.

      • Methods inherited from interface org.bukkit.configuration.serialization.ConfigurationSerializable

        serialize

    • Method Detail

      • contains

        boolean contains(org.bukkit.World w,
                 int x,
                 int y,
                 int z)
        Tests if the x, y and z points of the given world are within this region.
        Parameters:
        w - the world
        x - the x location
        y - the y location
        z - the z location
        Returns:
        true if the points are within the bounds

      • contains

        boolean contains(Place p)
        Convenience method for contains( p.world, p.x, p.y, p.z ). However, implementations may have optimised this method.
        Parameters:
        p - the place to test for
        Returns:
        true if the place is inside this region

      • shift

        Region shift(int x,
             int y,
             int z)
        Creates a new region that is the same as this region but shifted by the specified amount.
        Parameters:
        x - the x amount to shift by
        y - the y amount to shift by
        z - the z amount to shift by
        Returns:
        the shifted region
